comments.commentBody:
The thing about Brady is even with minutes left he was odds on to score.
Always dangerous. Always a good bet. I am sure the Jets never let that thought escape them. Ask them. They might have slept well Sunday night but in the back of their minds lingered the Brady comeback. Hats off to all of them for giving us a great game.

Why does Social Security need to be "retooled" for the 21st century? Harry Reid told Meet The Press that the arithmetic on Social Security works. It's fine, he said, and he's not going to be part of picking on Social Security. If the Times editors really care about poverty they should get on Reid's bandwagon and not be out in the tool shed compromising with themselves.

"We know it goes against the prevailing rhetoric to argue that more and better government policies are still needed to repair the economy."

President Obama's prevailing rhetoric, as expressed in his WSJ op-ed piece, is that excessive government regulations stifle economic growth. He has also reversed himself and now favors the Bush tax cuts for the rich, demonstrating that he has grown in office.

As a person who happens to have been raised in a devoutly Christian home and educated in Christian institutions, the religious aspect of these issues hits a nerve with me.  If the Republicans are the self-proclaimed party of Christianity, show us by their example by denouncing greed and giving their money to the poor without healthcare as Jesus commanded (they can give some of mine too in taxes), and stop pouring our tax dollars into lie-based unnecessary massive horrific violence (e.g., the War in Iraq) and the war-profiteering military industrial complex, precisely the thing Jesus said NOT to do.  Money for killing, but nothing for saving lives. By the way, Jesus condemned more than anything else, religious hypocrisy.

We cannot borrow to spend on the poor. Because once they consume the money, we will have to borrow more. And on and on and on.......until the poor will have no one to get money from. Then everyone will be poor, and no one will lend us again.

Ok Fran and mhr, so we spent over two years $875 billion to limit the damage of the recession- much of that went to bolstering state budgets and thus keeping much needed services (education for instance) intact. In total, government spending stayed roughly even when you consider state cuts. You can blow it up and say "Oh My God, $875 billion!", but in reality, it amounts to less than 3% of annual GDP in the US (given the two year time frame). If we think about this country as a family, I think I'd be willing to spend say $3000 of a $100,000 salary to help out my sick kid. But ask a rich person in this country to give up a few percentage points (on the margin!) and they scream bloody murder. The fact that the poverty rate increased marginally with the stimulus is a sign of how deeply disastrous this recession has been for so many. You folks must have nice, secure jobs, pensions, or are independently wealthy, because if you were jobless right now, you'd be singing a way different tune.

We've spent so much on the "safety net", and relaxed the requirements for getting into the "safety net" so much that it's no longer a "safety net".

It's a noose.

When poverty is high, wages are low, and business can hire more workers at lower wages (if they choose to).

Sounds like a win-lose situation to me.

2Fran in CA,

All you've demonstrated is that more should have been done. Perhaps that wasn't your intent.

We cannot afford the starvation and homelessness that would result with further cuts. The editorial is clear. There would have been millions more without the ability to put food on the table and even more homeless. The problem is and was that an sufficient amount of money was allocated was for the recovery act. Paul Krugman and others had recommended a trillion or more dollars. With inflation in food costs having increased 25% worldwide, if there are further cuts, we risk becoming like Tunisia and other places where people are rioting in the streets.

Why waste our time and yours with editorials like this? The people you are writing about are chumps, losers. Those who count appear on page 1 under the headline "Study Points to Windfall for Goldman Partners". They deserve an editorial celebrating their success, their riches. Instead you liberal types will want them to pay some outrageous tax rate. If they have any sense the  Republicans will push through legislation exempting incomes above a certain amount from any taxes at all. That provides an incentive to make a decent income. So what if the lazy are poor....if they wait outside the big banks and brokerages houses long enough certainly someone will come down and give them a slice of cake.

I was one of the very first to volunteer when the Peace Corps was  announced by President Kennedy in 1961. I was a junior in college and I wanted to graduate first.  I received a telegram in May of 1962 that I was chosen for the program in Malaysia, although it was Malaya then.  I still have the telegram.  I was a teacher in a technical school for Malays near Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.  I married a Chinese man that I had met there after I returned to the states. This experience truly changed my life.  I was in the third group to be sent to Malaya.  There were doctors, nurses, engineers, teachers and others who were "off to see the world" and make a difference.  Thanks for the opportunity.  D. Lim

The Peace Corps was a brilliant concept. It was in keeping with JFK's commitment to assist the poorest in the world, who had achieved newfound freedom at that time. It was also in keeping with his notion that the "torch" had been passed to a new generation, since many of us going into the Peace Corps at the time were just out of college. The hard part-- implementing the concept -- fell to Sargent Shriver. The Peace Corps could've easily failed during those early years. But, due to Sargent Shriver's brilliant execution, the Peace Corps became a huge success within a short span in those early years. It captured the imagination of an entire subsequent generation who have been tested in the field and have returned home to forge major changes. Sargent Shriver deserves as much credit for all of this as anyone over the past half-century. I'm proud to have served in the Peace Corps and to have returned home to push for progressive changes in every aspect of our society as a committed citizen dedicated to equal rights, international understanding, and poverty alleviation. Bruce, Guinea '64

Brian Cashman is now working with the Steinbrenner boys - NOT the Boss.  Things may not seem the same, in terms of their relationship and roles, but this could be an indicator that Cashman may not have complete autonomy.  I like the signing of Soriano, and it's way too early to panic. C'mon, Yankees have a great team, just needs to be tweaked a bit.

Me, I am much more interested in hearing about prospects for beefing up the starting rotation than I am in this non-issue. So he said he wouldn't, and he did? Maybe it was a negotiating tactic. Maybe he changed his mind. Maybe he was overruled. Who cares. Soriano is a good move.

A year ago we had Pettitte, Vasquez and Chamberlain all as potential or likely starters. All three are out of the running (I simply cannot imagine Joba back in the lineup, although I know others here disagree with me) and we've added only Ivan Nova, who is promising, but... Waiting for some further developments, Brian.

I would like to see a serious analysis addressed to this one question: How many of the contentious points concerning health care would disappear in a trice had we a single-payer system with a private insurance option? (Option, as in supplement; not opt-out)

My interest in the following is very practical, as I have two children who unexpectedly developed a rare illness that will require continuing medical care, and my family has always paid out of pocket for insurance.

Could you please give us an update on: (1)what new regulations about coverage guarantees have already gone into practice from the health care law that was passed; (2) which changes created by the law are currently set to go into effect, and in what year, if the law is not overturned; (3) which changes are likely to be vulnerable if the opposition to the law is successful.

I am especially interested in the regulation guaranteeing medical care for minors with pre-existing conditions (is there any price control?), and allowing children to stay on their parents' insurance for a few years past college. The success or failure of this law will help determine whether my family can return to our home state or must stay in Massachusetts, where insurance is well regulated.(PS-- we pay all our costs out of pocket, we work and pay taxes, and have not received any subsidies, but at least all doctors in MA seem to take most mainstream insurance.)

When it comes to truth in labeling, House Republicans are getting off to a poor start with their constantly repeated references to the new health care law as "job-killing."
We find:
Independent, nonpartisan experts project only a "small" or "minimal" impact on jobs, even before taking likely job gains in the health care and insurance industries into account.
The House Republican leadership, in a report issued Jan. 6, badly misrepresents what the Congressional Budget Office has said about the law. In fact, CBO is among those saying the effect "will probably be small."
The same study cited by the GOP also predicts an offsetting gain of 890,000 jobs in hospitals, doctors’ offices and insurance companies — a factor not mentioned by the House leadership.

The employer mandate would boost demand for healthcare goods and services, thereby increasing employment in healthcare-related sectors. The number of ambulatory healthcare professionals (...) needed will increase by 330,000. An additional 327,000 staff will be required to work in hospitals. Some 157,000 more nurses (... )will be needed to staff doctors’ offices, outpatient clinics, and other provider locations. And payrolls at insurance companies will expand by 76,000 workers.

From www.factcheck.org
Stop pouring our tax dollars into lie-based unnecessary warfare.  Money for healthcare, not warfare.
Another good question:  How is it the GOP gets away with such a savagely biased and partisan name for its proposal?

1964-66, English teacher, Adiyaman Turkey.
Unforgettable, a life forming experience.

What a spirit of idealism there was! It was a little naive perhaps, with the Vietnam War about to explode on our consciousness and affect our lives.

But such a different era from today. I think the world looks darker to my children and to my grandchildren, the oldest of whom is about to graduate from college.

The President of China doesn't seem friendly. That's just an impression. But conveying impressions is part of his job, isn't it? He must be trying to convey that.

If one puts one's odds with history, then all bets are off as to which country will be the more prosperous in the long run. China's celebrated success is already being measured by defunct standards - economic growth, in particular. Barring invasions, the future will favor countries where well-being is high and economic growth is low, because economic growth is not sustainable for more than a few hundred years. What's going to happen in China when no one wants to work their fingers to the bone in infernal factories anymore?

Looking at China and the US is like looking at two siblings, both outstanding in their own ways, but like oil and water. One free-spirited, creative but undisciplined, the other compelled by duty, self-negation and nationalism.

The US is down at the moment with little sign of turning around - Obama's election being a notable exception. But I would be uneasy putting long term odds on China. Until recently, the US made friends in many parts of the world and inspired many around the world. Although sullied, that capital is not gone. What friendships is China cultivating? What kind of feelings does China inspire? Awe, fear, maybe resentment?

Is it disappointing to be considered on the way out? Of course. But Europe shows that life in the valleys is generally sweeter than navigating over the ridges and peaks. We should wish China the best of luck and then focus a bit more on our own future. We're in the same boat with many other countries. Let's reintroduce ourselves and enjoy the company. China is, for the foreseeable future, in a boat alone.
The United States had no role in Baby Doc's return and does not benefit from it in any way.
I wonder what Edwidge Danticant thinks of the goings on in Haiti.

Francois "Papa Doc" Duvalier, Jean-Claude "Baby Doc" Duvalier, Jean-Bertrand Aristide, Rene Preval and the continuing Haitian tragedies - See www.wehaitians.com to read the complete article.

The writer, Yves A. Isidor, who teaches economics at the University of Massachusetts-Dartmouth, is exeutive editor of wehaitians.com

Does China really have harmonious society in herself?
Yes. She has a "harmonious society with Chinese characteristics".
Ask Uyghurs or Tibetans who were "being harmonized" in China. These two nations whose combined population is less than 20 million at most are at the risk of losing their culture, language, and may be themselves in the very near future to come, if the world buys "Made in China" brand of harmony.
Yes, China has made impressive economic progress over the past 3 decades and lifted hundreds of millions of Han Chinese from poverty, which is commendable, but she has taken away basic human rights of Uyghurs which is condemnable. Please do some research on Gheyret Niyaz, Gulnira Emin, and Ilham Tohti...They are all Uyghur intellectuals that were arrested and Jailed for writing the truth about Uyghur's predicaments.
